text: hi everyone welcome to the police state
here the Internet's busiest music nerd
and it is time for a review of the new
cheb alba record ano san Infierno this
is a new full-length LP from california
metal outfit cheb alba their latest for
the southern lourdes record label five
years after their previous LP tierra y
libertad it was an album I hoped they
would bounce back from a little bit as
it was a slight disappointment to hear
the band transition into a sound and a
production style that was not quite as
heavy as the break out hasta la muerte
because for me part of what made cheb
alba so special in the first place was
that their riffs their grooves their
breakdowns feature a lot of these
classic metalcore and beat down hardcore
formulas but they are delivered with the
heaviness the girth the gargantuan sound
of a doom metal record which given that
it's Southern Lord anything that
slightly trends in that direction is
going to be massively heavy now granted
some of the more doom metal esque
sounds on hasta la muerte were a little
derivative Greg Anderson of Sun even
featured on some tracks from the record
and I can understand how this may be a
sound you would want to drift away from
if you were looking to forge something
more unique or even improve upon this
but what happened on Tierra is that the
sound just got a lot tinnier the band's
writing style trended a lot more toward
death metal which I guess in theory is
fine but the sound quality just didn't
turn out to be nearly as good many of
the mixes on this project were so
chaotic the visceral performances just
weren't translating I think Anya's in
Infierno though is a happy middle ground
between these two records not derivative
Lee do me like hasta la muerte was on
occasion but that heaviness comes back
in a massive way while still managing to
make a record that leans more on the
death metal side of things like damn the
guitars and drums that open the first
track lot in just Asiya are actually
oppressive I am absolutely feeling
smothered by these riffs
mothered by these tongs as well from
which there is a lot of resonance in the
mix you really feel them ring and it
sounds so pummelling so massive and so
gargantuan mountainous without the mix
feeling too squeezed in claustrophobic
of course the vocals are really gruesome
too in delivery and tone but lyrics as
well depicting a series of ruthless
death squad murders structurally I don't
have a lot of complaints about this
track either as we get all of these
exhilarating transitions a great
breakdown and solo bridge now taking the
flow of the album into account the
following cut corridor de la muerte
feels like a slow melodic extension of
the opening track with a lot of loudly
ringing harmonized guitar leads very
primal drumming as well I appreciate the
band doesn't want this record to come
off as one note but I will say the
pacing is a little tedious with the
track Santa Muerte we have more sinister
death metal riffs matched with crushing
bass and drums the blast beats the
guttural vocals both have a classic
death metal abrasiveness to them but
still even this deep into the record
where it should be no surprise the
weight and the volume and the bass is in
the mix is something to behold the band
even makes sure to work in a really cool
doom metal passage just before the
midpoint of the song - so with another
combination of death metal and metalcore
and doom metal under our belts we have
the song Sokka which is yet another
instrumental mostly instrumental moment
on the project that is a little slower
more melodic we have these primal
pounding drums that sound like a march
to war as well as more soaring guitar
harmonies and while I continue to
appreciate the effort toward variety
here I am beginning to sense a pattern
in the tracklist when Shabab ax focuses
more on tracks that have less riffs less
lead vocals and more instrumental
passages more of a flecks of
compositional muscle it's not quite as
engaging while there are a few kick-ass
songs to follow this one in the
tracklist
the biggest test of the Bands
versatility comes by way of the two
six-minute closers
ellaby SMO parts
and to part one has this amazing intro
and build up that is just
larger-than-life one of the biggest and
most epic moments on the LP but then it
suddenly transitions into these watery
Reaver be dreary guitar chords that are
really thin and twanging it sounds like
something off of Metallica's black album
but slower with less in the way of
interesting melodies or songwriting
there's even some vocals faintly cleanly
singing in the mix that are just so
quiet they really don't even need to be
there it does not progress much it is
painfully repetitive if the band was
going to break their sound down this
severely I would have hoped that there
would be some kind of I don't know the
dynamic instrumental qualities to it or
something or that they would use this
space to fill it with an interesting
melodic idea or some lyrics that are
really gripping then with part two we
get these very peppy guitar chords that
sound almost like a progression you
would get from a pop punk song except on
this record they are just beefed up with
the fattest bass and guitar distortion
it's a weird delivery but okay it's a
refreshing change of pace I guess and
the band effectively makes these
slightly more upbeat chords work in
effectively with the more death metal
inspired passages without it sounding
too awkward but then immediately after
this those quiet and droning guitars
come back however at least on this track
they build up into something much
heavier however the death metal tone of
these guitars it's just way too sharp
shrill and abrasive to sound as blissful
or as meditative as I think the band is
is trying to make this song come off so
at the end of the day I'm still a little
torn on this new Shabab a-- record there
were some totally just head smashing
tracks on this one that i think are some
of their best yet then there's
everything else on the record that is
not that which to one degree or another
falls flat on its face while I do think
Shaba is still a unique band with a lot
of good ideas on this record and of
course I do encourage
them to continue pushing outside of
their comfort zone there are a lot of
tracks on this thing that I think could
have been better executed and I do
appreciate just how face melting a
majority of this LP is I am feeling a
strong six on this one transition have
you given this album a listen did you
love it did you hate it what would you
rate it you're the best you're the best
what should i review next hit the like
if you like please subscribe and please
don't cry the Bell is well over here
next to my head is another video for you
to check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel
Anthony Fantana Shabab ah forever
